importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei made a prediction about AI writing 90% of code within three to six months.
Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg predicted that in the next year, one project might have half of its development done by AI.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from March to October 2025 marks a wave of AI-related claims and debates about the impact of AI on software engineering productivity and workforce composition.

keyTakeAways: Tech CEOs such as Dario Amodei, Mark Zuckerberg, Amazon, Google, and Microsoft claim AI is rapidly transforming software development, with some predicting 90% or 50% of coding will be done by AI in the near future.
Despite ambitious claims, many software engineers are skeptical, citing AI-generated code that is difficult to understand, error-prone, or fails to improve overall efficiency.
AI tools are most effective for quick, low-accuracy tasks like prototyping, but struggle with complex problem-solving and high-level engineering judgment.
Studies show mixed results: a METR study found AI usage increased task completion time by 19% in experienced open-source engineers, while a Danish survey reported a modest 6.5% time saving.
AI adoption is often mandated or encouraged by management, leading to misuse or 'workslaps' — where AI is used inappropriately, resulting in messy, unworkable code.
Engineers are concerned about job displacement, especially of junior software engineers, and about the environmental cost of training large AI models.
Experts like Boris Cherny and Simon Willison emphasize that AI is a 'thought partner,' not a replacement — every line of code still needs human review and oversight.
The shift in startup funding — with Y Combinator now focusing exclusively on AI — reflects broader industry trends of AI-centric investment and rhetoric.

namedEntities.name: Dario Amodei
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He made a bold prediction in March 2025 that AI would be writing 90% of code within three to six months, fueling the debate on AI's role in software development.

namedEntities.name: Mark Zuckerberg
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He predicted in April 2025 that one project might see half of its development done by AI in the next year, reinforcing the trend of tech leaders embracing AI in coding.

namedEntities.name: Amazon
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Amazon promotes AI tools as helping engineers ship secure code and reduce busywork, though it does not mandate AI use and reports mixed engineer sentiment.

namedEntities.name: Google
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Google's survey of software engineers shows only a fraction of respondents trust AI responses, indicating skepticism about AI's reliability and effectiveness.

namedEntities.name: Microsoft
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Microsoft has highlighted the capabilities of large language models (LLMs) in generating code, contributing to the broader narrative that AI is transforming software engineering.

namedEntities.name: Anthropic
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Anthropic’s Claude Code unit developed AI agents capable of testing and rewriting code, though these tools are known to go into 'death spirals' and require human oversight.

namedEntities.name: Claude Code
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Claude Code is presented as an autonomous AI agent that can auto-resolve issues, but its effectiveness is limited, and it still requires human review and understanding.

namedEntities.name: Simon Willison
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He evaluates AI's role in software engineering, stating that AI improves productivity for experienced programmers on specific tasks but cannot replace human problem-solving.

namedEntities.name: Colton Voege
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He personally tested AI tools and found limited long-term efficiency gains, and is now considering starting a new business due to changing investment focus in AI.

namedEntities.name: Y Combinator
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Y Combinator previously supported diverse tech startups, but now exclusively supports AI-focused ventures, signaling a shift in investor priorities.

namedEntities.name: METR
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: METR conducted a study showing that experienced open-source engineers using LLMs took 19% longer to complete tasks, contradicting optimistic expectations.

namedEntities.name: Anders Humlum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Co-author of a Danish study on AI and productivity
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He contributed to a national survey in Denmark showing that AI saved engineers 6.5% of time, which is modest compared to other professions.

namedEntities.name: OpenAI
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Simon Willison was invited to preview OpenAI’s latest model, indicating industry-wide interest in evaluating new AI tools for code generation.

namedEntities.name: fly.io
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Thomas Ptacek, a software developer at fly.io, reports that AI helps reduce repetitive coding tasks, allowing faster iteration on familiar code.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Tech leaders including Dario Amodei of Anthropic and Mark Zuckerberg of Meta are making sweeping claims that AI is rapidly transforming software development, with some predicting AI will write 90% or half of code in the near future. However, software engineers such as Colton Voege and Simon Willison express skepticism, noting that AI-generated code often lacks clarity, leads to errors, and fails to deliver significant productivity gains. While AI excels at quick prototyping and repetitive tasks, it cannot replicate human-level problem-solving. Studies from METR and Denmark show mixed results, with some engineers taking longer to complete tasks and others reporting only modest time savings. Misuse of AI tools—often driven by management pressure—has led to inefficient or unusable code, a phenomenon dubbed 'workslaps.' Despite widespread adoption, only a fraction of engineers trust AI outputs, and concerns remain about job displacement, environmental costs, and the long-term sustainability of AI-driven software engineering. Experts emphasize that AI remains a supportive tool, not a replacement for human engineers, and every line of code still requires human review and oversight.
title: Tech CEOs Say the Era of 'Code by AI' Is Here. Some Software Engineers Are Skeptical
